abstract.p: Traditional clustering methods in Wireless Sensor Networks (WSNs) create energy distribution imbalances which shortens network operational time. The distribution of cluster heads becomes non-uniform because it does not respond to changes in node density or traffic patterns which leads to rapid energy exhaustion among specific nodes while other nodes remain idle. The unequal clustering technique offers adaptive node distribution and traffic load balance in response to this problem. The proposed method selects cluster heads through Coyote Optimization Algorithm (COA) optimization while fuzzy logic controls the adaptive cluster radii according to network conditions. Energy-efficient data routing is made possible through the implementation of a game-theoretic approach. Simulation analysis shows significant performance gains. The proposed method outperformed traditional EE-LEACH by extending network lifetime by 124.5% through its implementation. The network operational duration increases because the intelligent energy consumption management system distributes loads evenly across different network conditions. The proposed intelligent unequal clustering method demonstrates great potential to improve WSN performance. The combination of dynamic clustering with optimized routing systems leads to major improvements of both energy efficiency and network reliability as well as lifetime extension.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Smart technologies are already finding wide applications in different areas, including healthcare, construction, residential settings, aviation, and environmental monitoring. However, most smart technology-based applications completely depend on sensed data obtained from the real-time implementation environment1. Recent advances in Microelectromechanical Systems (MEMs) technology, wireless communication technologies, and digital electronics have facilitated the occurrence of sensors in smart environments2. Numerous low-cost microsensor devices capable of collectively detect, process, and send the relevant data in the area being monitored region make up a typical WSN. The combination of sensors, embedded computers, distributed data processing, and communication is embodied by WSNs. WSNs have been applied to many domains, taking advantage of their inherent strengths of perception, computation, and short-range communication in the Disaster relief, anti-terrorism, manufacturing, healthcare, traffic management, environmental monitoring, national security, national defense military, and other fields3. Recently, thanks to the development of hardware technology, stronger storage resources of a sensor node and its computing capability have shifted the primary usage area from indoors to outdoors4. Normally, it is hard to gain sensor node energy due to the unfriendly environment of the installed sensors5. Studies have shown that sensor nodes can expend up to 70% of their limited energy budget on wireless communication alone6. Therefore, efficient energy algorithms need to be designed to enhance the energy efficiency and, hence, the lifetime of a WSN network, remaining as one of our main goals7.

For environmental monitoring in a specific geographical area, there is a deployment of a sensor network with limited energy resources. Each sensor in the network is liable for periodically collecting information from the pre-defined monitoring range. Moreover, each node in this network performs all the tasks regarding data collection, receiving, analysis, and transmission. However, routing capacity is only available at few nodes. The transmission capacity is limited in most nodes. The sensor data is then collected and transmitted systematically through the network to the BS for more analysis. The wireless communication module consumes more energy as compared to other modules and the energy consumption of this module is directly proportional to the square of the distances among the transceiver nodes8. Without efficient management, this high communication cost can lead to rapid network partitioning or failure, sometimes within days or weeks depending on the application9. Clustering has been proven to be an effective routing technique that reduces the energy dissipation of nodes and balances the energy consumption of nodes to prolong the lifetime of the network10,11. Clustering techniques can be broadly classified as the division of nodes into individual groups of nodes called clusters. One leader node, referred to as a cluster head, and the other nodes, referred to as member nodes, comprise each cluster. Each member node transmits the sensed information to the associated cluster head, who collects, fuses with its own data after reception, and then forwards it to the BS. The BS is assumed to be unlimitedly energized and can communicate with the end user using a satellite, Internet, or any other means of communication media. It acts as an intermediate node between the BS and the sensor nodes. Creation of clusters and selection of suitable cluster heads (CHs) are important for minimizing energy usage12.

Traditional clustering methods establish clusters with equal sizes which results in faster energy depletion for base station proximate CHs compared to others13. The required adaptive approach for energy distribution requires unequal clustering methods that use smaller clusters near the sink to balance energy consumption14. Unequal clustering, which is one of the suitable techniques for enhancing the performance of WSNs, poses challenges in optimally determining cluster head nodes and also defining their sizes. Various methods have been proposed to address these challenges; some employ optimization techniques to determine cluster sizes, some follow random approaches, and others utilize mathematical models. In our proposed method, we combine the coyote search algorithm and fuzzy logic to address each of these existing challenges effectively. One of the innovations of this research is the utilization of the Coyote search algorithm in finding the optimum set of cluster head nodes based on characteristics and positional information, considering the parameters of energy levels, the number of neighbors, and the activity status of the node. Another innovation is the application of game theory at the network level for optimum routing; this very game model at this level improves traffic distribution, reduces energy consumption, and decreases end-to-end delays. The research makes explicit contributions to resolve the previously mentioned challenges through the following points:

list-item.p: This research adopts an innovative combination of intelligent optimization (COA), fuzzy logic and game theory to develop an adaptive unequal clustering with energy-aware data routing framework for WSNs.
A COA-based model serves to identify the optimal Cluster Head nodes by considering both residual energy and node degree parameters in WSNs.
The authors developed a Fuzzy Inference System model that enables distributed dynamic cluster radius optimization through CH centrality and distance metric analysis.

The researchers recommend establishing network connections between cluster heads through a game-theoretic system which optimizes energy usage by balancing reliability and distance against energy consumption.

sec.p: The paper follows this progression: research similar to the current one are examined in Sect. "Related works ". In the third Section, the proposed methodology is delineated, while in the fourth Section, the simulation results are discussed and the fifth Section, includes the conclusion.

sec.title: Related works
sec.p: We have reviewed in this section the recent studies on this topic. Tao et al.15 proposed an unequal clustering algorithm based on UCT2TSK fuzzy logic theory. With input variables including base distance, residual energy, and node density, the performance was boosted in both the network lifetime and throughput.

Sariga and Uthayakumar16 introduce a Type-2 Fuzzy Logic-based Unequal Clustering Algorithm (T2FLUCA) for maximizing WSN lifetime and eliminating hot spots, outperforming existing methods in terms of throughput and energy consumption.

Phoemphon et al.17 investigated Fuzzy Logic (FL) in clustering criteria and introduced a four-stage architecture, which produced encouraging results regarding network lifetime and energy usage compared to existing protocols.

Baradaran and Navi18 proposed HQCA, a high-quality clustering algorithm, for the optimal selection of cluster heads using fuzzy logic. Their approach had high reliability and a low error rate with improved scalability in large-scale networks.

Lekhraj and Kumar19 suggested the Visekriterijumsko KOmpromise Rangiranje (VIKOR) technique, a multi-criteria decision-making method for cluster head selection based on issues such as coverage, power, connectivity, distance, residual energy, and more power for a longer service life.
Sharma et al.20 introduced eeFFA/DE, a fuzzy-based clustering algorithm for optimizing energy efficiency in WSNs, which used distributed clustering and firefly and differential evolution techniques.
Mishra and Verma21 introduced a new Feed-Forward Multi-Clustering Protocol (FFMCP) that used fuzzy logic to enhance network lifetime, reduce member node distance, and distribute CH nodes uniformly.

Kousar et al.22 presented an improved hierarchical clustering approach in Mobile WSN (MWSN) based on Type-2 FL, named LEACH-MT2FL, which effectively provided a longer lifetime of the network while reducing packet loss in respect to existing schemes on energy consumption and packet delivery ratio.

Adnan et al.23 proposed a fuzzy logic-based clustering protocol that aims to efficiently perform data aggregation in multi-hop WSNs to reduce energy consumption and thereby extend the lifetime of such networks.

Rai and Daniel24 proposed a fuzzy Super Cluster Head selection method, which performed better than LEACH, SEP, TSEP, and CAFL concerning load balancing, stability, transmission of packets, and the lifespan of the network.

Dwivedi and Sharma25 proposed a new energy-efficient fuzzy logic-based clustering protocol called NEEF and compared it with SCHFTL and DFCR protocols with better performance in stability periods, packet forwarding, average energy, and extended lifetime.

Ali et al.26 explored the use of WSNs multipath routing for energy efficiency, scalability, and balanced load, demonstrating high network resilience by reducing energy consumption and packet loss rates.

Reddy et al.27 presented a hybrid algorithm entitled Ant Colony Optimization (ACO) integrated with Glowworm Swarm Optimization (GSO) approach (ACI-GSO) for energy-efficient routing in WSNs; the performance was evaluated and efficiency proved over conventional methods.

Dwivedi28 aimed to decrease energy consumption in WSNs by utilizing clustering processes like CH determination, cluster formation, and data dissemination. Simulations showed improved energy utilization and dead node ratio compared to LEACH and MOD-LEACH algorithms.

Anand and Pandey29 proposed a scheme to extend network lifetime in WSNs using clustering based on a genetic algorithm and particle swarm optimization to enhance energy efficiency and system survival. Table 1 presents the summarization of the studied research.

Al-Qurabat et al.30 introduced an IoT WSN energy conservation method by implementing the SAX + LZW compression technique at sensors and gateway-operated redundant data filtering. The research results indicated sizeable power conservation combined with enhanced operational duration for the network versus other solutions while omitting specific details about potential computational expenses.

Idrees et al.31 developed DaReCA which serves as an energy-saving framework for IoT WSNs by implementing leader cluster algorithms at sensors and aggregator-based dataset merging. The evaluation demonstrated lower transmission rates alongside data integrity preservation without specifying any abstract restrictions. The authors of32 used Fuzzy C-Means (FCM) to create an energy-saving clustering system for WSN-based IoT by selecting CHs based on cluster energy consumption while implementing an energy-based CH rotation mechanism.

The researchers at Abdulzahra et al.33 invented the EFUCSS protocol by integrating unequal clustering based on FCM with fuzzy logic for CH selection and sleep scheduling for optimized WSN-based IoT energy management. Simulation results achieved substantial enhancement of lifetime duration yet the paper disregarded integration challenges. Abdulzahra and Al-Qurabat applied FCM for energy-aware clustering and CH selection in WSN-based IoT through dynamic CH rotation which depended on energy levels in their work34. This study shared similarities with32 by attempting to extend network life duration, but did not discuss FCM weaknesses.

table-wrap-foot.p: Although there have been many contributions in the literature towards energy efficient clustering in WSNs, there are still some research gaps:.

list-item.p: Dynamic Cluster Formation: Most of the current solutions are based on the formation of clusters that are fixed, while the conditions in the network are dynamic. Our proposed method can overcome this limitation by defining the cluster size in terms of positions of the nodes and traffic load.

Energy-Efficient Routing: Although, there are some researches on energy efficient routing, still further research is required in order to achieve the optimal energy consumption and the maximum network lifetime. Based on the game theory, our routing strategy for the data transfer is designed to enhance the throughput while reducing energy consumption.

Robustness to Node Failures: Most of the current methods are vulnerable to node failures. The approach we proposed can improve the network’s ability to handle node failures because it is distributed and uses multiple communication channels.

Scalability: However, some of the existing approaches may not be well suited to large-scale WSNs. The method we propose, utilizing efficient optimization algorithms and distributed decision making, is suited for large scale networks.

sec.p: With these gaps in mind, our proposed model can provide a valuable contribution to the field of WSNs. It is a simple and scalable solution to the energy consumption problem in clustering and routing, resulting in better network performance and longer network life.

sec.title: Research method
sec.p: In this section of the paper, a multi-faceted approach is presented to address the challenges of energy efficiency and network longevity in WSNs. Unequal clustering is utilized to achieve a balance between energy consumption and network coverage. To this end, the COA is employed for selecting cluster head nodes with high energy efficiency, followed by a fuzzy logic-based model to determine the optimal dynamic cluster radius based on network conditions. Subsequently, an energy-aware routing protocol is designed to efficiently transmit data through the hierarchical cluster structure. The goal of this combined strategy is to increase network longevity and enhance overall network performance. The theoretical foundation of this integrated methodology relies on using individual techniques to address specific combined challenges that exist in WSN clustering and routing. The authors combine established optimization approaches (evolutionary optimization, fuzzy logic, game theory) because WSN performance optimization requires complex multi-objective solutions. The COA serves cluster head selection because it shows success in navigating complex search areas to find optimal solutions while maintaining exploration and exploitation balance which identifies high-quality cluster head options throughout the network35. The fuzzy logic system manages network uncertainties and linguistic ambiguities when determining cluster radii from dynamic node conditions through expert rule-based systems36. Game theory introduces data routing models because it describes cluster heads’ rational behavior toward maximizing utility while conserving energy for network data delivery tasks and allows researchers to analyze stable routing strategies through Nash Equilibrium concepts37. The combined approach enables cluster formation based on network conditions followed by data routing that operates through the established structure using equilibrium-based methods. Following the introduction of assumptions and the network model, the steps of the proposed method will be explained.

sec.title: Network model and assumptions
sec.p: Additional assumptions employed in this model encompass:

list-item.p: Random and fixed deployment of nodes: Sensors are scattered in the environment randomly, and once deployed, their positions do not change.
Distance estimation using signal intensity: The distance between nodes can be determined by measuring the strength of the signal received from each node.
Node heterogeneity refers to the fact that each sensor node have distinct beginning energy levels, buffer capacities, and radio power.
The fixed base station location refers to the particular and unchanging position of the base station within the network environment.
Given these assumptions and the system model’s characteristics, we may formulate a suitable mathematical model to simulate and assess the effectiveness of the suggested strategy.

sec.p: The network model contains assumptions which are typical for WSN simulation research39. The simulation model incorporates three main assumptions which include stationary sensors and base station devices alongside signal strength-based distance calculations without complex interference modeling and Poisson traffic modeling. The first-order radio energy model (Eqs. 1 and 2) which is commonly cited in38 provides only an abstract representation of actual energy consumption. The defined assumptions establish the boundaries of this research to evaluate the core performance of the proposed clustering and routing logic against other algorithms within controlled experimental settings. The routing cost function contains a normalized queuing delay term (qij in Eq. 12) as a component. The usage of qij in Eq. 12 brings basic congestion awareness but future research must focus on detailed network simulation of complex effects together with realistic hardware experiments.

sec.title: Proposed clustering algorithm
sec.p: Here, we will explain the details of the presented clustering algorithm. The proposed algorithm is an asymmetric and competitive clustering method. The advantage of this approach lies in leveraging the social intelligence of the COA to select the optimal cluster structure in the network, aiming to reduce the consumed power and increase network operational capacity. Initially, each node’s fitness for selection as a cluster head is calculated by the coyote search algorithm. After this process, each node communicates its selection probability to its neighbors, and then, by comparing their neighbors’ conditions with their own selection probability, each node determines if it should be a cluster head. After selecting the cluster heads, the process of determining the cluster size is performed by the cluster head nodes using a fuzzy inference model based on the connectivity properties of the cluster heads. Once the clusters are formed, data routing within the established structure takes place. With these explanations, the operations carried out in the proposed algorithm can be divided into the following steps:

list-item.p: Selection of cluster heads using the coyote search algorithm.
Determination of cluster size by cluster heads and formation based on fuzzy logic.
Data routing in the clustered network.

sec.p: In the following, we will explain each of these steps.

sec.title: Cluster head selection using Coyote search algorithm
sec.p: In the proposed method, the selection of cluster heads is carried out using the coyote search algorithm. The COA algorithm was chosen for this work among Genetic Algorithm (GA), Particle Swarm Optimization (PSO), Ant Colony Optimization (ACO), and even more recent metaheuristics such as Sand Cat Swarm Optimization (SCSO)41, and Artificial Rabbits Optimization (ARO)42 because of several important factors. COA derives its concepts from coyote social structures and hunting behaviors to provide an optimal combination of search phases which benefits cluster head configuration searches in dynamic WSN environments35. The COA demonstrates advantages over many well-known metaheuristics because it typically uses fewer parameters and includes a unique population adaptation process that combines birth/death operators with group interactions which helps it escape local optima in particular problem domains35. The social nature and adaptive qualities within COA deliver an acceptable model for WSN cluster head selection through distributed decision-making despite challenges in proving sweeping superiority of metaheuristics across applications. Our aim is to leverage these characteristics to effectively address the fitness criteria defined for energy-efficient clustering. In this section, the encoding of the solution vectors in the optimization problem, as well as the evaluation of their fitness, are first explained. Subsequently, the steps of searching for the optimal combination of cluster heads using the coyote search algorithm are presented.

The most crucial part of an optimization algorithm is its fitness function. A fitness function describes the value of a solution. Therefore, using the fitness function, it can be determined which of the sensor nodes in the network is more suitable for selection as a cluster head and which response obtained by the search algorithm is optimal. In the proposed method, the coyote search algorithm selects the best cluster heads using the following criteria:

list-item.p: The number of selected cluster heads in the current response.
Energy of the selected cluster heads.
The number of neighbors connected to the selected cluster heads.

sec.p: Following the computation of the fitness for each node by the coyote search algorithm, the search process proceeds to find the optimal clustering of active network nodes. The algorithm iterates until the fitness of the response reaches the target fitness or until the algorithm reaches a specified number of iterations. The search steps using the coyote search optimization method are as follows:
Step 1: Randomly determine the first population comprising p groups, each of which contains c coyotes.
Step 2: Calculate the fitness value for every solution (coyote) according to Eq. 3.
Step 3: Repeat steps 4 to 13 until the minimum fitness reaches zero or the number of algorithm iterations reaches the threshold T.
Step 4: For each group of coyotes, repeat steps 5 to 11:
Step 5: Determine the coyote having minimum fitness value in the group as the alpha coyote.
Step 7: For each available coyote c in the group, steps 8 through 10 are repeated:
Step 9: Use Eq. 3 to calculate the new fitness value for the current coyote.
Step 10: Update the social position of the coyote based on changes in its fitness.
Step 11: Apply birth and death operators to the current group.
Step 13: Update the ages of the coyotes and proceed to Step 3.

In our implementation, the COA parameters were set based on common practices in the literature and preliminary experiments to ensure effective exploration and convergence: the population size was set to 100 coyotes, divided into p = 10 groups, resulting in c = 10 coyotes per group. The algorithm terminates when either the maximum number of iterations, T = 100, is reached, or a solution with the target fitness is found, as indicated in Step 3 of the algorithm description.

The above steps, return a solution having minimum fitness. Then, the nodes marked with the number 1 in this solution vector are chosen as CHs. Once the CH nodes are determined, each node communicates its selection probability to its neighbors. Subsequently, each node determines its own cluster head status by comparing the received values from its neighbors with its own selection probability. A node selects itself as a cluster head only if its selection probability is greater than the values received from all its neighbors. In the next step, the process of determining cluster sizes and forming clusters will be carried out, which we will delve into next.

sec.title: Determination of cluster size by cluster heads and its formation
sec.p: Cluster formation by cluster heads in the unbalanced clustering method requires determining the size of each cluster separately. The introduced approach uses the fuzzy logic for determining the radius of each cluster. This fuzzy system determines the radius of the cluster using the global criteria of the cluster head nodes. The proposed fuzzy inference system in the proposed method uses three global criteria of network nodes to determine the radius of the clusters and form the clustered topology of the network. sec.p: This research study uses a limited range of network density variations to perform its performance evaluation in Sect. 4 but the designed fuzzy logic system maintains adaptability for different network densities. The system demonstrates robustness because it calculates input variables from current network topology and CH properties before applying fuzzy rules (Table 2) to these relative inputs. The research still requires validation across different deployment patterns and network densities through further studies for future development.

After determining its cluster size, each cluster sends a message to its neighbors within its radius to invite receiving nodes to join the cluster. It is worth mentioning that to address the issues of wandering nodes and unclustered nodes in the network, should such nodes be found within the network, they will join the nearest cluster within their vicinity. Following the formation of clusters, data routing takes place within the clustered network.

sec.title: Data routing in clustered network
sec.p: Upon completion of the clusters, the data routing process occurs. In this regard, a game theory-based model is employed. The data routing process exclusively takes place through the cluster nodes. To simplify the routing problem, the network structure is considered as a supply and demand model. In this case, from a routing perspective, network nodes are categorized into three groups:

list-item.p: Cluster Head Source: Sensor nodes generating data packets for routing.
Intermediate Cluster Heads: Nodes able to participate in routing packets towards the destination.
Destination Node: The base station, serving as the destination for all data packets and assumed to have an unlimited energy source.

sec.p: In the assumed supply and demand model, the base station node will reward the nodes participating in routing that packet with a value R once it has successfully received the current data. Similarly, the source node will pay a reward Pi to every intermediate node, xi, involved in the routing process. This is considered to be constant for all intermediate nodes to make the computations easier and is represented as a constant, P. As a result, every cluster can participate in the game strategy if it calculates a positive payoff and be part of the data transmission path. In other words, the payoff received from data transmission is higher than the cost incurred in terms of energy and distance to transmit that data.

sec.title: Examining Nash equilibrium in the game model
sec.p: The analysis proves that the routing game possesses a Nash Equilibrium under the established model framework together with its stated assumptions. It provides theoretical support for the stability of the paths selected based on the utility function (Eq. 10) in our simulation environment. Practical WSN deployment faces operational hurdles when maintaining equilibrium because of the energy-usage and queue-status state-reporting overhead and also because of the requirement to achieve swift convergence during network dynamics. The theoretical and simulated work extends only to basic analysis since future development for real-world implementation will require attention to practical deployment considerations.

sec.title: Complexity and scalability analysis
sec.p: Multiple computational elements within the proposed approach lead to an increased level of complexity. The qualitative examination demonstrates the following sequence of operations:

list-item.p: Fuzzy Logic Radius Determination: A CH requires minimal computational resources to determine its radius after the fuzzy inference system design because it only needs to perform fuzzification of inputs and rule evaluation and defuzzification steps. The model complexity remains low because it uses 3 input variables and 18 rules thus contributing minimal overhead compared to the optimization phase.

sec.p: Scalability: The clustering overhead grows when network size (N) increases because the COA search space dimensionality expands which may require more optimization iterations (T) or population size (P) thus increasing clustering demands. The network size and density determine the extent of communication overhead required to exchange information about COA fitness calculation and game strategy parameters and fuzzy logic inputs.

Latency Consideration: The route calculation method of the game-theoretic framework causes processing delays at CH nodes which exceeds time requirements compared to standard routing protocols. A longer latency per hop remains an accepted disadvantage to support superior routing choices which deliver both better energy conservation and longer network operation times. The actual time delay depends on the hardware characteristics of the nodes along with current network traffic conditions.

sec.title: Implementation results
sec.p: The proposed approach was implemented in MATLAB 2020a through simulation. All the simulation experiments were repeated 20 times, and the average of the 20 repeated results was reported. We conducted a comparative analysis of the proposed method with three reference methods, namely ACI-GSO, EE-LEACH, and GA-PSO, as documented in references27–29. These methods were implemented using the same parameters and specifications of the simulated environment. Also, the traffic pattern of the compared models was considered same as the pattern considered for the proposed algorithm. The general parameter set of optimization algorithms in27,29 was the same as COA in proposed method; with population size of 100 and 100 iterations. Table 3 describes the simulation parameters.

sec.p: Network consumed energy is displayed in Fig. 5. To better evaluate energy use, we set the nodes’ initial energy value to 0.5 joules. The proposed strategy is compared to three others in this figure. The y-axis indicates cycles while the vertical axis shows joules of energy use. As seen in this graph, the proposed approach uses less energy than others in all cycles. This illustrates that the proposed method has drained network node energy at a reduced slope or rate, increasing network lifetime. Thus, unequal clustering to construct the network topological structure directly increased lifetime.

The network’s remaining energy is illustrated in Fig. 6. This graph shows how network nodes in different cycles have maintained greater power. The proposed method loses less energy than the compared methods, and the GA-PSO method, which uses energy-dependent routing operations and cluster determination, is closest. Our method uses dynamic adjustment and unequal clustering to boost energy efficiency more than GA-PSO.

Figure 7 illustrates the number of packets sent in relation to the number of different cycles. Our method sent more packets than others, as shown in this graph. Thus, our network nodes were better used. Our method came closest to the ACI-GSO method in this graph. In routing, our technique outperformed GA-PSO and EE-LEACH. This approach consumes more energy than ours, thus after approximately 1100 cycles, the number of surviving nodes and transmissions is reduced. Our energy-efficient routing algorithm has reduced routing energy usage significantly. This has increased network transmissions and node survival.

Figure 8 illustrates the average network lifetime, comparing the proposed method to three other approaches. The graph demonstrates that the technique in question has the longest network node lifespan and surpasses all others. The network’s lifetime increases as the number of nodes grows, due to the increased availability of energy resources and their more efficient utilization. All techniques show an ascending trend in this graph, but the method in focus exhibits a greater extension of life compared to the others, validating that the approach to network energy resource management is superior.

Figure 9 displays the number of packets sent to network members based on the number of different nodes. This graph illustrates that the method still transmits more than the others. The proposed routing method employing ACI-GSO minimizes data transmission energy consumption, extending the network’s lifetime and preventing nodes from squandering energy. sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: This paper introduced a new approach to overcome the energy depletion problems of clustered WSNs, using unequal clustering. which includes three steps: first, the use of the COA in the choice of cluster heads; then, it dynamically determined the size of the cluster according to the identified cluster heads by use of local fuzzy logic models. Finally, to perform the routing, a game theory-based model was used, which discovered the best routes for data transmission between cluster head nodes. Simulation experiments under the defined network model (Sect. "Network model and assumptions ") assessed the proposed method using various metrics. The results indicate promising effectiveness in reducing energy consumption and improving packet delivery compared to baseline algorithms for the evaluated scenarios.

The simulation outcomes show promise but researchers must recognize the fundamental constraints of this research which mainly stem from the simplifying assumptions in the network model (Sect. "Network model and assumptions "). The research incorporates static nodes together with a fixed base station and a first-order radio energy model without hardware verification and does not include complex channel modeling. The optimization and game-theoretic components in the system create computational overhead that can produce latency trade-offs which need evaluation when deploying the system in practice (Sect. "Complexity and scalability analysis"). The current findings are bounded by these factors while suggesting research directions for future work. The research work opens new avenues for future study which include:

list-item.p: A distributed version of the COA-based cluster head selection process requires development for complete decentralization and reduced communication expenses.
The evaluation process needs to include dynamic WSN conditions through mobility models to examine how the algorithm performs when nodes move within the network.

A more realistic channel characteristics analysis should be incorporated into the network model to evaluate how the protocol withstands complex radio environments with interference effects, fading frequencies and collision disturbances.

Real sensor hardware tests on physical WSN testbeds should be performed to directly measure the practical performance and energy consumption and communication overhead of the proposed approach when compared to simulated results.

The exploration of novel and mixed metaheuristic optimization methods should be studied for cluster head selection phase because this combination might boost solution quality and speed up convergence time.
The researchers should modify game-theoretic cost functions for QoS requirements that include minimal end-to-end latency or maximal data delivery reliability.
The system’s performance should be tested for different traffic patterns which extend beyond Poisson distribution to determine its application range.
